lNGPXGiAXAjvXfAxf4FNLw.text: A personal go-to for comfort food. You can customize the level of spiciness you want in the curry as well as the amount of rice, toppings, etc.Overall a safe bet for a hearty meal. Certainly not the best curry since it's a bit fast-food-ish but still a very good choice. Personal favorite is the Tonkatsu curry. I would recommend going for this classic dish since I'ts the best combo with Japanese curry. Have tried the salmon and shrimp curries as well - which are also good but just don't go as well compared to the Tonkatsu

na7ti48wpt1-HtbOP5GtXA.text: Coco ichibanya has been one of my favorite Japanese cuisine. As my standard, I only can take level one spiciness. I like their omelette too but this time, I chose their croquette curry set. But their rice isn't quite enough for me though. Their rice are only half of the plate size. But thumbs up for their curry! Always my love. Will be trying out the other set next time.

photos.caption: Photo of CoCo Ichibanya - Singapore, Singapore. Curry set

0Ri-tSi_gfv3SbtyZUt_RA.text: We ordered the squid curry rice (normal spicy level), with add ons of pork cutlet and additional rice and curry (level 3!). The serving was enough for two! Service was great, and the side mini salad was well done. The pork cutlet remained crispy despite being half dipped into the curry sauce. The squid came with mayo topping as well. Great experience dining here.

photos.caption: Photo of CoCo Ichibanya - Singapore, Singapore. Pork cutlet rice + curry, side salad and green tea

jwfz_D98_uYy2dSgMnqtjw.text: The Pancake Wave in Japan at might be the motivation behind the launch of pancakes at the Westgate outlet and it is the first overseas outlet to do so. (You can't find pancakes in any Japan outlets either). But pioneering new items are attached with great risks. Outlook were not very optimistic for the pancakes, which had a common problem of being too weighty, dense and chewy. Portion size is good for desserts but the whipped cream wilted badly at the mercy of the heat emitted from those fresh-of-the-griddles batter. There are currently four variants - Caramel Nutty Pancake, Banana Choco Pancake, Rainbow Fruity Pancake, and Happy Berry Pancake. So perhaps it may be good to practice some patience and await a better batch of 2nd-generation pancakes as the recipe undergoes a revamp. In the meantime, keep calm and try some of the unique curry that meets the local tastebuds. How can Japanese curry be so spicy that it sets off a burning sensation on the tongue? Yes, chilli heads will be delighted to know that one can get some kick-ass curry at Coco Ichibanya, if you order the highest level 5. I took up the challenge to have a taste and it approximates close to our punchy Southeast Asian Sambal.  But for those who love the classically sweet Japanese curry, go for level 0.Instead of going for the recommended items such as Creamy Mushroom Omu or Pork Cutlet Cheese, we placed our bets on the Salmon Croquette with Mushroom Curry($15)-level 2. The mildly-spiced gravy made up for the flatly mediocre salmon croquettes, which came with tiny salmon cubes. The idea of customizing your curry level apply to all except for the Omelette rice series. The Pork Cutlet Omelette Curry Rice ($15) with a maximum spice level 3, had a less-than-runny omelette. The breaded Pork Cutlet was crunchy coupled with curry of a faint, fugitive heat.These curry rice meals don't encourage you take petit bites, they exhort you to dig in. Interestingly, the curry here is made with 17 different spices! I was quite impressed by the spiciness of their curry and now I am contemplating to take-away some of the level 4 gravy to go with some fragrant roti-bun next time!

photos.caption: Photo of CoCo Ichibanya - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of CoCo Ichibanya - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of CoCo Ichibanya - Singapore, Singapore

vPQMmGMsUHdIQF5MpySiZA.text: Came across this place for a bit especially when it is located at orchard. It was normally packed but I was fortunate enough to be seated straightaway on a Tuesday night. While looking at the menu, the price seems decent considering it is located at the central where tourists might pass by when they are shopping for goods.What attracted while browsing the menu was the pork cutlet curry. While ordering, the waiter even told us what's cheaper or what's not - set or separate dishes. He also asked about how much rice I wanted as well as the level of spiciness.Curry wise it is comparable to the curry house restaurants in Southern California. But Katsu wise I just like the breaded flour. Rice wise it is considered good for that price.Food wise - 3 stars and adding the other star for customer service especially for the waiter named Jun Jie. Will come back again for the curry but might be ordering shredded beef ones instead. Bon appetit!!

photos.caption: Photo of CoCo Ichibanya - Singapore, Singapore

lfIiMncFAF1a_0hphHu-Xg.text: I'm sorry but this taste something out of a pre mix Japanese curry pack. More fragrant with redeeming pork cutlet. but other than that, I'll give it a miss.Japanese cuisine has touched many people's stomach and I think even a ongiri can outperform this dish

iM9qbBo-np1k_1SV2fjgoQ.text: Decent jap curry but not mind blowing. Prices range from about $13 for a basic plate to about $20 after add onsA lot of choices and variety in terms of what protein /seafood base you want. A lot of options to vary spice level and other toppings as well.

photos.caption: Photo of CoCo Ichibanya - Singapore, Singapore. Pork cutlet jap curry level 1 (this is the max hottest level for me that's comfortable)
Photo of CoCo Ichibanya - Singapore, Singapore. Creamy mushroom curry - mild level 0

dsDbayCPTWLkvhGl4ihkpw.text: Honestly I don't know what's the hype about for the Jap curry here. I think it taste rather normal and has the same level of quality as compared to other jap restaurants in SG. I ordered the vege curry with pork cutlet, the vege in the curry has the taste of the fridge which I really don't appreciate. I am definitely not coming back here!

photos.caption: Photo of CoCo Ichibanya - Singapore, Singapore. Pork cutlet and vege curry rice

Xo6kCc9wiHS5-bUlN7EUkA.text: You can customise the amount of rice, the ingredients in your curry and the level of spiciness at this place. With so much variety that can arise from such a system, it's hard to not like what you order! Of course, you get what you pay for...I miss the curry I had when I was in Japan, and though this wasn't exactly the same, it came pretty close. Getting here is a cinch as its conveniently located. Service is fairly fast and the staff are flexible as well. Overall, its good enough to keep reminding me of the delicious curry I had in Japan.

photos.caption: Photo of CoCo Ichibanya - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of CoCo Ichibanya - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of CoCo Ichibanya - Singapore, Singapore

twHbUqLef8Iqb01JoQl8PQ.text: It's been 20 years since I last went to a CoCo Ichibanya.  As a student in Nagoya, Japan, near ground central of the original store, CoCo Ichibanya was a nice option and one that was readily available.  But after moving back to the States, I haven't been able to go to one until now.  Some things haven't changed in 2 decades - tasty curry offered at a low price.  What has changed is that there are many more options - options to customize as well as combinations, such as hamburger and cheese, omelette, noodles, salads, etc.  After trying curry at a few other Japanese restaurants, CoCo wins - ok, it's not really haute cuisine, but it's a familiar taste for those familiar with Japanese curry and executed well, e.g. no lumps, smooth texture, adjustable levels of spiciness.  I stuck with a classic- Curry wit ha pork cutlet, and while the pork cutlet was ok, the curry really steals the show, as it should (for a better cutlet, definitely check out Saboten in the same building).  While it's a huge chain, it's nice to have the option here in Singapore!

i6fjKF5gwUAYkwMmClZ4xQ.text: Craving for a Good Plate of Japanese Curry rice? Then here is the place to be. This restaurant which has gained notable popularity since it's first branch opened in Somerset 313 serves up good Japanese curry. The unique thing about this particular restaurant is that you can customize your own rice, from the simplest meal of just your main dish, you can also adds sides or toppings. You can also order the level of spiciness to cater to your taste buds. But a warning to those who can take really spicy food, the level of spiciness may just kick you out of your shoes! Situated in Somerset 313, it is definitely the best place to dine after a long day's work, as it is quiet and peaceful around the mall.

6XZ3Bsddkmpi9DCqYSPcGw.text: Curry fever hits Singapore and this is one of the premium curry houses in Singapore after Go Go curry in ION closed down.Well, the challenge of Coco Ichibanya is to be able to take their level 5 curry (which I proudly declare am able to) which is extremely spicy. Prices start from $14 onwards for a simple katsu curry and goes slightly more expensive for dishes with omu (omelette) and beef. What's better is that each add-on is clearly stated in the menu and the prices are clearly shown. Normally I would ask for some extra rice (a bit pricey for rice, but it is absolutely required when taking on the spicy challenge).The curry is thick and consistent but the katsu is quite small in size. But really, that katsu is not the star. The curry is and it is absolutely great in terms of spiciness.Be warned that level 3 onward is really spicy and one should proceed with caution.

wY8d7q8gKrHmjCnuHT8XPg.text: Would you be surprised if I told you Japan ranks second in terms of world consumption of curry? Behold, that is really the truth! No wonder the popularity of the Japanese curry has also spread here. Currently, there are two Japanese curry joints that opened in Singapore and one of them is Coco Ichibanya. The one at the Somerset is the first outlet and has got me hooked since then! You can make your customize your curry rice, whether you want less rice or more rice, the side dish/topping to go along with it, and even the spiciness (mild to level 5). The main, which is the curry, is really creamy and goes well with the rice, no matter which level you choose. There's a common misconception that Japanese curry is not spicy, which is not true. Personally, level 2 is already quite spicy. So if you want your curry more spicy, you can just go up the level! Convenient location, lively and comfortable dining environment, delicious curry, great companionship, there's nothing more to ask for!
